content.text: Bash crontab Command - Schedule Tasks
Understanding Cron and Crontab
The cron system is a time-based job scheduler in Unix-like operating systems.
content.html: The cron system is a time-based job scheduler in Unix-like operating systems.

content.text: It automates the execution of tasks (known as cron jobs) at specified intervals.
content.html: It automates the execution of tasks (known as cron jobs) at specified intervals.

content.text: While cron is the background service that runs these tasks, crontab is the command used to manage them.
content.html: While cron is the background service that runs these tasks, crontab is the command used to manage them.

content.text: There is no direct "cron" command; instead, you use crontab to set up and control cron jobs.
content.html: There is no direct "cron" command; instead, you use crontab to set up and control cron jobs.

content.text: Using Crontab
The crontab command allows you to define scheduled tasks.
content.html: The crontab command allows you to define scheduled tasks.

content.text: These tasks are specified in a crontab file, which is a simple text file containing a list of commands meant to be run at specified times.
content.html: These tasks are specified in a crontab file, which is a simple text file containing a list of commands meant to be run at specified times.

To run a script every day at midnight, you would use:
